title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.12.23 | 28-08-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: So here three comparisons are made.
segments.summary: The speaker introduces verse 23 of the 12th chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam and explains the three comparisons made in the verse regarding the qualities of child Pariksit to Yudhishthira/Brahma, Shiva, and Narayana.

segments.key_quote: In both cases, the comparison is equally good because both of them are recognized representatives of the Supreme Lord.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the comparison of Pariksit to Yudhishthira and Brahma in terms of mental equanimity, explaining their roles in welfare work and how they represent the Supreme Lord.

segments.key_quote: Anyone in a position of responsibility has to have that equanimity of mind to do the welfare work in spite of criticism from the very people whom they are trying to do welfare activity.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the challenges of welfare work, using the example of Brahma being criticized by the gopis for creating eyelids, and emphasizes the importance of mental equanimity in the face of criticism.

segments.key_quote: Lord Shiva is a celebrated demigod who awards gifts to beggars.
segments.summary: The speaker transitions to the comparison of Pariksit to Lord Shiva in terms of munificence, describing Shiva's generosity and using the example of Ravana to illustrate how easily obtained gifts can be misused.

segments.key_quote: Lord Shiva never denies anyone any sort of gift. He is very liberal.
segments.summary: The speaker continues the discussion of Lord Shiva's generosity with the story of Vrikasura, who received a dangerous benediction from Shiva and was ultimately stopped by Vishnu, highlighting the potential downsides of indiscriminate giving.

segments.key_quote: Instead of seeking directly the protection of the goddess of fortune, one should seek the protection of Vishnu.
segments.summary: The speaker moves to the comparison of Pariksit to Lord Vishnu, emphasizing Vishnu's role as the maintainer of all living beings and the ultimate source of protection, even for the goddess of fortune, and contrasting this with the illusory nature of material economic development.

segments.key_quote: Only Vishnu or his pure devotee can give protection to everyone.
segments.summary: The speaker concludes by reiterating that only Vishnu or his pure devotee can provide true protection, and that Pariksit Maharaj, being protected by Vishnu, would offer protection to those under his rule.
